Message.Title: Why Jim Mcgrag and eetimes could be wrong about Antutu benchmarks.
Message.Msg: RISC instructions vs CISC. The Intel compiler probably optimizes for CISC, by combining multiple RISC instructions into their CISC equivalent. That could be why many of the instructions excecuted by ARM benchmarks are not executed by Atom. The point is not how many instructions get executed, but is the task done. Until we get Intel's side of the story, my bet is the Intel Atom and baytrail kick butt, and eetimes can go sniff Mr Weaver!!

Topic.Title: One trade + $4,500 On the day..

Message.Msg: MIVG

Topic.Title: Why Jim Mcgrag and eetimes could be wrong about Antutu benchmarks.

Message.Msg: It's got nothing to do with RISC v CISC. Intel replaced a GCC generated binary with an ICC one The ICC binary used a different set of compile switches than GCC (which turned on the SIMD instructions for x86) The ICC binary 'skipped' parts of the benchmark Doing any one of the above invalidates the benchmark score.

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: How do we know Baytrail beats the best ARM SoC's? We only have Intel's figures and how can we trust them now that we know that Intel have been (lets be kind) "optimizing" the benchmarks? This PR stunt is going to backfire on Intel. If your tech is genuinely better than the comp, let it do the talking and keep the marketing guys out of it.

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: The "non-executed instructions" were ones that any smart x86 programmer wouldn't use. x86 offers many faster instructions. Yes, we're comparing oranges to apple here, and the oranges (x86's) taste better. The other benchmarks don't allow these features and the inefficient ARM chips win. It's like having a war where nukes aren't allowed and the jungle guerillas win. hmmm, er, to be polite about it...our tech is better.

Message.Title: Why isnt Intel PR responding to the AnTuTu disaster??
Message.Msg: Everyone on the Web are calling Intel "cheaters" & Intel PR does nothing, hoping it goes away. I'm sure it was an honest misunderstanding, but Intel has to get on top of it. I thought the new Intel CEO would be more transparent & shareholder friendly...I guess I was wrong. This is going to blow up badly if Intel ignores it.

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: Clearly my alter ego knows little about programming. It's the compiler that spits out the instructions not the programmer and it's the various switches that define what, if any, of the advanced instructions are used (ie, SIMD). If this had been the other way around, say with QCOM and it's snapdragon 800: Use ARM's compiler (like Intel's, it's better than GCC which is the compiler used for Android) Use 03 as one of the compile switch's (to enable ARM's SIMD instructions) Use aggressive optimization so parts of the benchmark code is not even executed Would you be crying fair or foul? In the scheme of things, the "optimization" of one benchmark is a none event. However, much has been made of this benchmark for current and future Intel SoC's and will cause a lot of PR damage to Intel's cause.

Message.Title: Why the Samsung design win matters
Message.Msg: According to Dan Farber at CNET, Apple and Samsung are going to hog most of the profits from mobile devices. Intel's Samsung design win could be its "foot in the door" to this lucrative market. If they could convince Samsung not to produce their inferior application processors, they could get their chips into most of their devices and get a part of the revenues from this growing market. Besides, Samsung is at least two process nodes behind Intel on fabrication so with Intel accelerating their process development, it's a no-brainer for Samsung to make the switch en-masse.

Topic.Title: Why Jim Mcgrag and eetimes could be wrong about Antutu benchmarks.

Message.Msg: It is way early to be putting too much stock into the benchmarks but I think what most of us have been saying is that on paper at least, Baytrail should easily outperform an equivalent ARM chip. I don't think you are ever going to get any ARM biased writers to ever admit that ARM will under perform an INTEL chip. The common mantra of these people is that ARM chips are inherently more efficient then an equivalent INTEL chip. They are wrong of course, but they will continue to cling to that view regardless dismissing any evidence to the contrary.

Topic.Title: Why Jim Mcgrag and eetimes could be wrong about Antutu benchmarks.

Message.Msg: The compile switches are turning on optimizations. Skipping parts of the benchmarks is your interpretation of what happened. Mcgrag clearly said skipped "instructions".

Topic.Title: Why Jim Mcgrag and eetimes could be wrong about Antutu benchmarks.

Message.Msg: Yes, compile switches turn on/off optimizations. When you do benchmarking you make sure you are comparing like for like (given the limitations on the enviroment). Same version of the OS, same version of the compiler, same compiler settings etc. The default setting for Antutu was Os for all ISA's (optimize for small size), this was changed for Intel's binary. The skipping parts of the benchmark is the effect of the 'skipped' instructions. It's basically doing something like: if (CPU is Atom) { ignore this part of the benchmark; } else { do this part of the benchmark } Albeit it on a smaller scale. Do a google for anandtech forums AnTuTu and Intel and you can see the details.

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: There are compilers and there are compilers. An optimized x86 compiler will use mSMI's (specialized machine instructions) and that is a specialty of Intel chips. My guess is that this is evolving with the new Intel penetration into mobile, while ARM has been around a long time and compilers are already optimized for them. IMO, the comps where ARM beats Intel are all optimized compiled for ARM, and unoptimized x86. If so, the shoe is on the other foot, and Intel will beat ARM in all tests. Surely you won't force Intel chips to wear lead boots in these comps? It's my opinion, however, I haven't studied this allegation in detail.

Topic.Title: Why isnt Intel PR responding to the AnTuTu disaster??

Message.Msg: One view ..... Intel did not publish anything and has no reason so respond. The results were a leak and any response will highlight their existence and give them legs. Intel did not tout any results and has no reason to reply, other than to say someone violated their confidential agreements in Asia. Someone in China ran some version of the AnTuTu benchmarks and results were automatically, anonymously submitted. Intel (nor many other tech companies) have been able to keep their Asian partners/vendors from leaking Intel confidential information (roadmaps). AnTuTu (likely) routinely compiled their benchmarks with the Intel compiler for the first time (probably with the same compiler switches they were using before with gcc) and did nothing other than that. The gcc compiler AnTuTu was using knew something about the Atom Saltwell core BUT not about new changes for Silvermont. AnTuTu likely wanted to use the compiler that at least "knew" about new Atom instruction set, out-of-order scheduling, silicon resources, .... to get a representative result. Intel probably wanted to make that available to them for their work. Bay Trail is the first Atom to support SSE4 instructions for example. Benchmarks are hard and making them correctly is near impossible.

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: I suggest you do study it, because if the claims are true... Android is linux, and the OS/native apps are compiled with GCC. It's x86 that has the advantage due to the maturity of the software stack (especially the compiler). ICC (Intel's compiler) produces some of the best code that we've tested (x86 server based software), and if it was just switching the compiler then you *may* be able to argue it, but then it becomes a compiler test not a CPU test (as the parameters aren't the same)

Topic.Title: Why Jim Mcgrag and eetimes could be wrong about Antutu benchmarks.

Message.Msg: Dude, Compilers don't skip parts of code. They optimize it. Furthermore, ARM is RISC which means it takes more instructions to do the same thing as CISC. Intel's compiler is just doing the same thing as ARM with LESS instructions. Anyway, its all speculation right now, until we hear from the real parties involved.

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: If the claims are true, then some engineer at AnTuTu made a mistake by not fully analyzing the impact of a new complier had on his benchmark. If the claims are true, then a 1.1GHz Bay Trail-T will probably perform lower ( about -20% ?) than the China leaked result. If the claims are true, then compiling your Android Linux x86_64 application with the Intel ICC complier that supports gcc extensions will make your Android Linux x86_64 run faster. I think those statements are accurate.

Topic.Title: Why Jim Mcgrag and eetimes could be wrong about Antutu benchmarks.

Message.Msg: "Intel replaced a GCC generated binary with an ICC one" Do you know if Intel did the recompile? "The ICC binary used a different set of compile switches than GCC (which turned on the SIMD instructions for x86)" Do you know what switches were used? I suspect that a "target Bay Trail" switch was added so the compiler would generate out-of-order Atom code. My bet is that WHOEVER used the compiler on the AnTuTu benchmark source code, used the standard gcc switches. I cannot find where AnTuTu has even released their source code, either public domain or for sale. Do you have information about getting it?

Message.Title: Fake Outrage
Message.Msg: The current controversy over the benchmarks is pretty funny given the incredible distortions that the ARM foundries have put out over the last two years about their fabrication roadmaps and arrivals of full volume production. The benchmark interpretations are absolutely nothing in comparison. And whether Intel crushes ARM on this set of benchmarks or the next is meaningless. Bottom line is that due to Intel's solid and growing fabrication superiority, Intel is going to crush ARM on both performance and power efficiency. The war is over and ARM has lost. ARM fanbois need to stop trying to spin this into something that is going to change the basic reality that the ARM era is over. It's over. Stick a fork in ARM and this meaningless controversy. Take a strong look at the incredible distortions that the ARM foundries have put out over the last two years about their fabrication roadmaps and arrivals of full volume production.

Topic.Title: Why Jim Mcgrag and eetimes could be wrong about Antutu benchmarks.

Message.Msg: I've written x86 and ARM assembly code, I know what I am talking about. This isn't an RISC V CISC issue. Yes, compilers do *skip* code - when they think the result isn't needed for further calculations (it can be a source of bugs that I personally have had to deal with). Do a search for dead code elimination for further details.

Topic.Title: Fake Outrage

Message.Msg: Is it your outrage that is fake? If this was an Intel dirty trick, then I am disgusted. However, I am already disgusted by the competition. We have to dig deep into this. If the optimization of the code used by AnTuTu is justified then it is the other benchmarks that hand an undeserved advantage to ARM (that;s what I think is the case). I have written compilers in the old days, and knew the old guys at Caltech when Intel was a baby. But I am too far removed to dig into this now. Someone who knows something, and isn't just a shill like my dual, has to figure this out. Marsavian?

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: "Bay Trail beats Arm best Soc in power and performance by wide margin." He's probably right. And this "Intel PR stunt" is a pretty prejudicial label, coming from someone who struts around in a gown like a Supreme Court Justice. The fact is, eveything is going to backfire in the ARM/QCOM/TSMC-verse.

Topic.Title: ARM Beats Intel With Revised AnTuTu Benchmark

Message.Msg: The issue isn't with Bay Trail (directly), it's with clover trail+ and the article by ABI (as it's results where based on the Antutu benchmark). Yeah, compiling the android kernel and apps with ICC will make things faster, but the same would happen if you built the the whole thing with ARM's compiler (it's also better than GCC) - and like ICC you have to pay for it. FYI, when you build for x86_64 (on GCC at least), it automatically includes support for SSE2 (or is it 3? I can't remember) and other flags as a minimum CPU standard for x86_64. Looking at the assembly in the article, it looks like it's 32bit (ie, x86) - do a Google for: anandtech forum AnTuTu and Intel and the first hit should be it. It will give you all the answers - and no double more questions:)

Topic.Title: Fake Outrage

Message.Msg: I happen to agree with wallis on this one. Just the same, the unrevised AnTuTu benchmark is the correct way to do the benchmark and it fits reality operations better. In any case the ship has sailed and whether or not Intel is better or on par. Atom may not be yet the ARM-buster that the ABI Research report made it out to be. But for the first time in a long time, Intel has products that can legitimately compete with ARM and take a big chunk from it's market share. kudos

Topic.Title: Two Tech Giants Lead the Dow's Gains

Message.Msg: I took the 1.7% decline in mobile devices from Gartner but you may be right. IDC thinks they grew at 4%. I was talking about phones in general and not the smart devices. Their grown will roll over as the market matures. Gartner: 2012 mobile phone sales declined 1.7% worldwide; Apple iPhone sales up 22.6% YOY Wednesday, February 13, 2013 · 9:58 am Worldwide mobile phone sales to end users totaled 1.75 billion units in 2012, a 1.7 percent decline from 2011 sales, according to Gartner, Inc. Smartphones continued to drive overall mobile phone sales, and the fourth quarter of 2012 saw record smartphone sales of 207.7 million units, up 38.3 percent from the same period last year. “The last time the worldwide mobile phone market declined was in 2009,” said Anshul Gupta, principal research analyst at Gartner, in a statement. “Tough economic conditions, shifting consumer preferences and intense market competition weakened the worldwide mobile phone market this year.” IDC echoed your thoughts of a slowing growth. Worldwide Mobile Phone Growth Expected to Drop to 1.4% in 2012 Despite Continued Growth Of Smartphones, According to IDC 04 Dec 2012 FRAMINGHAM, Mass. December 4, 2012 – The worldwide mobile phone market is forecast to grow 1.4% year over year in 2012, the lowest annual growth rate in three years despite a projected record number of smartphone shipments in the high-volume holiday season. According to the International Data Corporation (IDC) Worldwide Quarterly Mobile Phone Tracker, vendors will ship more than 1.7 billion mobile phones this year. In 2016, IDC forecasts 2.2 billion mobile phones will be shipped to the channel.

Yet the Razor I seamed to be faster and more energy efficient. RAZR I RAZR M Quadrant 4,226 4,944 Vellamo 1,928 2,442 SunSpider 0.9.1 (ms) 1,077 1,951 AnTuTu 6,175 6,364 GLBenchmark Egypt Offscreen (fps) 41 56 CF-Bench 3,115 9,392 Here is some of endgadget's conclusions "We also had the chance to pit the RAZR i against the Droid RAZR M. Aside from the benchmark results outlined above, the Medfield entry offered a marginally faster response to most actions. " "...In addition to this admirable performance, we were interested to see how Intel's mobile chip fared in terms of battery life -- with the Motorola RAZR M sharing screen similarities and more, we can make a better judgement on whether those promises stand up. On our battery rundown -- video playback, 50 percent brightness, WiFi and 3G on, social networks and email on sync -- Intel's iteration lasted nine hours, compared with eight hours for the RAZR M. Topic.Title: Marsavian, your thoughts on teh AnTuTu debate?

Message.Msg: Storm in a teacup. Clovertrail's strength is not performance but performance/power and that has not changed. Its eventual battle is taking out all the quad-A7s on performance/power/price next year when it is superseded by Silvermont. I also think the most important benchmarks are real application ones like Anand runs not all these ancient #$%$ contest ones like antutu, dmips etc. The only serious cross architecture benchmark is SpecCPU and for that you are allowed to use the best compiler for your cpu as that is part of the delivered experience. If you look at the blurb for BayTrail the overall performance claimed for it is an amalgamation of about 15 apps/benchmarks so nothing will change for it. Intel is still undervalued as it is improving its processors across all markets quicker than its competition and that will not change going forward.

Message.Title: Dell now shipping XPS 12 Ultrabook/tablet with Intel Haswell processors
Message.Msg: Summary: The refreshed convertible laptop also adds Near Field Communication Dell launched the XPS 12 last fall as one of the first Windows 8 notebooks that could switch between laptop and tablet modes. Last month the company announced that it would be adding Intel's new Haswell processors to an updated version of the device, and this week Dell has started selling the refreshed 2013 XPS 12. As anyone following Intel's launch of the fourth-generation Core CPUs knows, the Haswell chips offer improved performance while strengthening battery life. Dell is claiming that the new processors will boost the XPS 12's speed by 1.6 times and battery life by 2.5 hours. In addition to the Haswell upgrade, Dell has given the XPS 12 support for Near Field Communications, letting you transfer files by tapping an NFC-supporting device to the Ultrabook. The expected battery life jump will help overcome one of the XPS 12's weaknesses, based on Sandra Vogel's review from earlier this year, which otherwise praises the system's swiveling screen and overall design. From ZDNet

Message.Title: Intel’s ‘Haswell’ 4th gen chips now in SL
Message.Msg: [Gee, do we think that Gartner and IDC have good sources of PC sales information in Sri Lanka? No, we don't. Do we think if Haswell chips are in Sri Lanka that they have spread to just about everywhere in the world? Yes, we do...] Sri Lanka’s Intel unit debuted its fourth generation ‘Core’ line of chips last week, following the first time launch of this, its latest generation, codenamed “Haswell”, at Taiwan’s Computex 2013 mega exhibition at the beginning of June. According to Intel’s Director of Strategic Initiatives for South Asia Rajiv Bhalla, the fourth generation Core chips now only requires six watts to function, at its most basic levels, which rises to as much as 95 watts for chips typically utilised in data centres. He also noted that this means that a devices battery life could be extended by as much as 50 per cent, in addition to doubling graphics performance, and allowing for a 15 per cent overall CPU gain. He also noted that the new chips added capabilities such as a seven-day standby time for mobile devices, and a less than three-second wake-up from sleep mode. Also emerging in a statement issued by Intel; “All new Ultrabooks using this technology will be touch-enabled and have Intel Wireless Display capability built in to bring natural touch and motion interactivity and speed mode for low-latency gaming on the big screen”. Additionally, the statement also revealed Intel to be working on the premise that, by 2016, all TV, video-on-demand and Internet video, combined, could represent as much as 86 per cent of global consumer traffic. From the sundaytimes

Topic.Title: 5 years from now is this a 10 dollar stock?

Message.Title: ET deals: $769 for Lenovo Y410p Haswell laptop
Message.Msg: With PC shipments dropping every quarter, manufacturers can’t afford to charge premiums on new models like they used to. Instead of sticking closer to the “list price” that they used to offer on brand new models, they pick up right where they left off with market prices. This means that even though we’re looking at a refreshed model with the new Intel Haswell processors, pricing is as competitive as we saw on the 2012 Ivy Bridge models. This holds true for today’s deal, which offers a solid performance upgrade over 2012 models at a price point that rivals anything we’ve seen in the past year. This IdeaPad Y410p stuffs the quad-core Core i7-4700MQ and 2GB Nvidia GeForce GT 750M graphics card into a 14-inch chassis that is still rather petite at 5.5 lbs and 0.59-1.29 inches thick. Also standard on all models is 8GB of RAM, a 1TB hard drive, and backlit keyboard. Lenovo IdeaPad Y410p - closeup The connectivity list is strong with one USB 3.0 port, two USB 2.0 (one of which will charge a mobile device), 6-in-1 card reader, and both HDMI and VGA outputs. Intel’s 2230 802.11n WiFi card and Bluetooth 4.0 are also standard on every model, leaving only three real options to choose between different models: an HD+ 1600×900 screen, 24GB mSATA SSD, and Blu-ray drive. With this sale, you can snag the well-equipped base model with Core i7, 8GB, 1TB HDD, and HD screen for $769 after coupon. For a little more coin, you can step up to a version with the HD+ screen and 24GB mSATA SSD at $849. These prices are incredibly competitive in the Haswell laptop space and will hopefully help make a few gamers very happy. From extremetech

Message.Title: Tape-Outs
Message.Msg: On the other hand, Xilinx now wants you to know that they are the first in the industry to tape out at 20nm, and you know what THAT means! Wait, you don’t? You know - “tapeout” - it’s the part of the chip development process where you are “done!” I mean, “done,” except for the huge amount of stuff that has to happen after tapeout and before production. So, anyway, they’ll have some 20nm chips for us all - in something like a few months to a year or so. But, we already knew that. FPGA companies don’t usually announce when they hit tape-out. But, if you need a reason to make an announcement or if your bag of superlatives is looking a little lean, why not? From eejournal [Yep, as Nenni and all the ARM fanbois on this board tell us: Tape-out is where you are done. LOL...]

Message.Title: Microsoft Surface RT Tablets Price Cut Begins Sunday Staples; Widespread Sale?
Message.Msg: Microsoft is cutting the price of its Surface RT tablets by $150. Staples has confirmed the rumor by selling just the 32GB RT model at $350 starting Sunday, July 14, and ending Saturday, July 20. However, it is unclear if the discount also extends to the 64GB version and whether the sale is temporary or permanent. From the gospelherald [Expect the dumping of RT to soon be extended to ARM stock...]

Message.Title: AnTuTu Benchmarks - More Questions
Message.Msg: There was an initial AnTuTu benchmark where CT+ scored high by 'skipping' parts of instructions. The 'problem' was fixed and the benchmark was revised, bringing down the CT+ score substantially. I think it is possible that both benchmarks are valid in different contexts. The former is representative of a real world scenario where x86 compiler optimizes the executable to skip 'unnecessary' instructions. However, for the pure hardware test, competiting processors need to execute the same (or equivalent) set of instructions, even if that means executing unnecessary instructions. This is what was done in the revised benchmark. I am just talking about the possibility, don't know what is the real case. But if the above thought is true, CT+ and successors will have additional advantage in running the real world applications - through compiler optimization. In real world situations, CT+/BT will run as fast as the first AnTuTu benchmark. Another question is why does AnTuTu benchmark need C/C++ compiler, whether ICC or GCC? Is it based on C/C++ code? Does it bypass Java based Android OS on Android platforms and directly deal with the processor? Please share your knowledge and thoughts.

Topic.Title: AnTuTu Benchmarks - More Questions

Message.Msg: I assume Intel continues support for automatic vectorization, which can generate SSE, SSE2, SSE3, SSSE3, SSE4, AVX and AVX2 SIMD instructions, and the embedded variant for Intel MMX and MMX 2. Use of these instructions through the compiler can lead to radically improved application performance in applications on IA-32 and Intel 64 architectures, compared to applications built with compilers that do not support these instructions. To insist on some idiot's restricted optimization makes these benchmarks, the world of my alter ego, Suprem Court Justice blueredmonkey, more assinine than I had appreciated. Of course..the performance on these complex instruction set Intel chips will dwarf what we see now. Antutu shows what a tiny tweak can do. People should get their heads out of these meaningless benchmarks, and put them somewhere where there's more light and it smells better..
